tear.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: a drop of salty liquid that comes out of your eye when you are crying
tear.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The children were all in tears.
She came home in floods of tears.
I could see that Sam was close to tears.
Bridget suddenly burst into tears and ran out.
He was fighting back tears as he spoke.
A lot of people were moved to tears by his story.
He kissed her cheek, a gesture that brought tears to her eyes.
I must admit I shed a few tears when the school closed.
I saw grown men reduced to tears that day.
‘Please don’t talk like that, ’ Ellen implored him, her eyes filling with tears.
By this time, tears were streaming down my face.
The tears he shed were tears of joy.
tear.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: be in tears
When Evelyn put the phone down, she was in tears.
be in floods of tears
By the time she left, she was in floods of tears.
be close to/on the verge of tears
He could see that May was close to tears.
there are tears in somebody’s eyes
As she watched, there were tears of joy in her eyes.
tears of joy/frustration/rage etc
The tears he shed were tears of joy.
burst into tears
She burst into tears and begged me to stay.
break down in tears
I broke down in tears when I read the letter.
be moved to tears
Members of the audience were moved to tears by her singing.
bring tears to somebody’s eyes
This unexpected kindness brings tears to my eyes.
reduce somebody to tears
His insults had reduced her to tears, but she had not changed her mind.
hold back the tears
She gave her version of events, often struggling to hold back the tears.
fight/choke/blink back tears
She fought back tears yesterday as she re-lived the horrors she had seen.
shed/weep tears
Don’t shed any tears for him.
somebody’s eyes fill with tears
His eyes filled with tears as he recalled his mother’s sacrifices.
tears well up in somebody’s eyes
She broke off, feeling the tears welling up in her eyes.
tears run/roll/stream down somebody’s face
Oliver laughed until tears ran down his face.
bitter tears
She wept bitter tears of remorse for leaving her children behind.
hot tears
I felt the hot tears running down my face.
tear.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to damage something such as paper or cloth by pulling it hard or letting it touch something sharp
tear.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Be careful not to tear the paper.
His clothes were old and torn.
The dog had torn a huge hole in the tent.
He picked up the envelope and tore it open.
She tore the letter to pieces and threw it in the bin.
Most of her clothes had been torn to shreds.
She realized she had torn her jacket on a nail.
Tear off the slip at the bottom of this page and send it back to us.
He tore a page out of his notebook and handed it to her.
tear.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: if paper or cloth tears, it splits and a hole appears, because it has been pulled too hard or has touched something sharp
tear.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The paper is old and tears easily.
tear.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: to run or drive somewhere very quickly, especially in a dangerous or careless way
tear.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: She tore back into the house.
We tore down to the hospital.
tear.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: to pull something violently from a person or place
tear.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: He tore the letter from my hand.
A bridge was torn from the bank by the floodwaters.
High winds nearly tore the roof off the house.
tear.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: to damage a muscle or ligament
tear.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: She had torn a muscle in her leg.
tear.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: She caught her shawl on a nail and tore a hole in it.
The dogs tore the meat to pieces.
Jack snatched the letter from him and tore it in two.
tear.translation[1].note_box[1].sections: tear
to damage paper or cloth by pulling it too hard, or letting it touch something sharp
She unwrapped the present carefully, trying not to tear the paper.
I tore a hole in my jacket, climbing over the fence.
rip
to tear something quickly or violently
Beth excitedly ripped open the package.
Stop pulling my dress! You’ll rip it!
to tear your trousers or shirt when you put them on, because they are too tight for you
He bent down and split his trousers.
Oh no, now I’ve split my shirt.
ladder
if a woman ladders her tights or stockings, she tears them so that a long thin line appears in them
Damn! I’ve laddered my tights!
snag
to catch a piece of clothing on something rough or sharp so that it tears slightly
I snagged my shirt on a nail.
shred
to deliberately destroy letters, documents etc by cutting them into thin pieces, often by using a special machine
In order to prevent fraud, it’s best to shred your bank statements.
I went through all my papers shredding things I didn’t need.
frayed
torn a little along the edges – used about clothes, carpets etc that have been used a lot
He was wearing an old pair of frayed jeans.
The rug was a little frayed around the edges.
The jacket was a little frayed at the cuffs.
tear.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: a hole in a piece of cloth or paper where it has been torn
tear.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: There was a huge tear in his shirt.
tear.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: if your eyes tear, they produce salty liquid, for example because of cold air or smoke
tear.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: Why does cutting up onions make my eyes tear?
